title: Citi Defines New Companies for Trading BDRs in the Brazilian Stock Market
summary: Sao Paulo, Brazil - On August 5, Citi Brazil and the Securities and Exchange Commission of Brazil (CVM) filed an application to begin trading 10 new Brazilian Depositary Receipts (BDRs). This was done in connection with the fourth competitive bidding process established by the Brazilian stock market (BM&FBovespa). The 10 foreign companies selected by Citibank were Qualcomm, Amgen, Verizon Communications, Comcast, Linkedin, Philip Morris, Netflix, Ford Motors, Halliburton and Dell.
tag-1: Citi Defines New Companies for Trading BDRs in the Brazilian Stock Market
tag-3: Sao Paulo, Brazil – On August 5, Citi Brazil and the Securities and Exchange Commission of Brazil (CVM) filed an application to begin trading 10 new Brazilian Depositary Receipts (BDRs). This was done in connection with the fourth competitive bidding process established by the Brazilian stock market (BM&FBovespa). The 10 foreign companies selected by Citibank were Qualcomm, Amgen, Verizon Communications, Comcast, Linkedin, Philip Morris, Netflix, Ford Motors, Halliburton and Dell.
tag-4: The bank is awaiting authorization to issue the BDRs, in order to set the date to begin trading the shares in the Brazilian stock market.
tag-5: This is the second set of Unsponsored Level I BDRs that Citi will make available for trading on the BM&FBovespa. Last year, the bank won the first bidding process, offering shares of 10 foreign companies – Alcoa, Cisco Systems, Citigroup, Freeport-McMoran Copper & Gold, General Electric, Intel, Merck, Microsoft, Procter & Gamble and Wells Fargo.
tag-6: The Unsponsored Level I BDR is a certificate issued by a depositary institution in Brazil that represents stocks issued by publicly traded companies, with headquarters overseas. For this reason, the transaction is considered an overseas investment. The issuing and registration process is the responsibility of the depository institution in Brazil, with no participation of the companies involved in the trading of securities.
tag-7: The new BDRs that will be issued by Citi can be traded by financial institutions and investment funds, in addition to portfolio managers and securities advisors authorized by the CVM – the last two using their own funds. Pension funds, individuals and legal entities are also authorized to negotiate Level I BDRs, sponsored or not, if those investments exceed R$1 million.
tag-8: The BDRs will be traded in reals and prices will be determined by the shares' price in the United States according to the dollar rate in Brazil on the date of purchase and liquidity conditions of the shares in the Brazilian market.
tag-9: Citi, the leading global financial services company, has approximately 200 million customer accounts and does business in more than 160 countries and jurisdictions. Citi provides consumers, corporations, governments and institutions with a broad range of financial products and services, including consumer banking and credit, corporate and investment banking, securities brokerage, transaction services, and wealth management.
